trial_identification.studytitle: A randomised clinical trial of interpersonal social rhythms psychotherapy in young people with bipolar disorder.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomised clinical trial of interpersonal social rhythms therapy with non-specific supportive clinical management in the treatment of young people with bipolar disorder to reduce the cummulative burden of depressive symptomatology over the period from 6 to 18 months after starting treatment.

interventions.interventions: Interpersonal social rhythms psychotherapy (IPSRT). Duration: 18 months.
interventions.comparator: Non-specific Supportive Clinical Management (NSCM). Duration: 18 months.

primaryOutcome.outcome: To evaluate the hypothesis that Interpersonal Social Rhythms Psychotherapy (IPSRT) is superior to a "control" psychological intervention (non-specific supportive clinical management (NSCM), in improving the medium term (6-18 month) outcome of young people with bipolar disaffective disorder, who are also receiving psychopharmacological treatment.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Analysis will be completed following the 18 month treatment protocol.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Primary outcome is decreased cumulative burden of depressive symptoms.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Analysis will be completed following the 18 month treatment protocol.

Analysis will be completed following the 18 month treatment protocol.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: (a) able and willing to sign informed consent for the research protocol. Patients may be on any medication, or combination of medication when they enter the study.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: (a) schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder; (b) severe alcohol or drug dependence as a principal diagnosis; (c) low probability of remaining in contact with treating clinicians.
